name: Koreas talk for the first time in two years
voc: [('invaluable','extremely useful'),('foolproof','impossible to get wrong'),('break (the) ice','reduce tension')]
desc: North and South Korea have met for high-level talks for the first time in two years. Among the topics for their discussion were next month's South Korean Winter Olympics, which North Korea has agreed to attend.

name: Time's Up
voc: [('launch','start a large project or initiative'),('harassment','repeated unpleasant behaviour which upsets or annoys someone'),('unveil','officially announce something new')]
desc: More than 300 actresses, writers and directors have started an initiative to help fight sexual harassment in the film industry and other workplaces.

name: Used rocket launched into space
voc: [('re-usable','able to be used again'),('launch','when a spacecraft is put into space'),('milestone','event which marks an important stage in a process')]
desc: An American company has launched a used rocket into space for the first time. Spacex wants to revolutionise space travel and - eventually - make it possible for people to live on other planets. They have been searching for ways to make this more affordable. One those ways is to use rockets that have already flown.

name: Gatlin team doping allegations
voc: [('embroiled','deeply involved in a difficult situation'),('expose','public report exposing the facts of a situation'),('bombshell','sudden and unpleasant piece of news')]
desc: World champion sprinter, Justin Gatlin and his team have been implicated in doping allegations as the result of an investigation by two undercover journalists for the British newspaper The Daily Telegraph.

name: Macron renews global warming fight
voc: [('flock','come together in large numbers'),('offsets','balances or counteracts'),('undercut','weaken or make less important')]
desc: French president Macron hopes to re-energise the fight against global warming, and that American president, Donald Trump, will join in.

name: Global pollution: seeking solutions
voc: [('Armageddon','a highly destructive event'),('pact','formal agreement'),('rampant','increasingly out of control')]
desc: Ministers from around 100 countries are meeting to finish a declaration to fight global pollution.

name: A royal romance
voc: [('smitten','in love'),('dysfunctional','not working properly'),('(as) thick as thieves','very close and private')]
desc: Prince Harry, fifth in line to the throne, is going to marry American actress Meghan Markle.

name: President defies a nation
voc: [('an ultimatum','a threat of punishment if someone does not do something'),('ebbing away ','becoming weaker'),('buying it','believing it')]
desc: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe has refused to step down despite demands from his own party, ZANU-PF.

name: Italy World Cup fail
voc: [('scathing','strongly criticising'),('goes ballistic','suddenly becomes very angry '),('goes begging','is free to be taken')]
desc: Italy, four-time champions, have failed to qualify for the World Cup for the first time in 60 years.

name: The Russian Revolution: 100 years on
voc: [('low-key','without much activity or excitement'),('lessons','experiences that help people make better decisions in future'),('the promise of','the hope or suggestion something positive will happen')]
desc: Low-key events are being held in Russia to mark the 100th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

name: Human health affected by climate change
voc: [('taking a toll','causing harm or damage over time'),('swelter','feel uncomfortably hot  '),('flee','escape quickly from a dangerous place')]
desc: A new report on climate change has concluded that rising temperatures are seriously harming human health.

name: Toxicity tax for London's polluting cars
voc: [('curb','control or limit something'),('template','something copied to produce similar items '),('exempt','excused from following a rule')]
desc: The T-charge, a new daily tax on London's worst polluting cars, has been introduced.

name: Ancient stellar collision makes waves
voc: [('sparking','causing to begin'),('ripple','small wave(s) of something '),('comb through','examine thoroughly')]
desc: Two dead stars, which collided 150 million years ago, have made gravity waves and proven Einstein's prediction correct.

name: Racial inequality in the UK
voc: [('take action on','begin to do something to solve a problem'),('lays bare','makes something known which was hidden'),('glaring','obviously bad or wrong')]
desc: A person's race has an impact on their life chances in areas such as health, education, and criminal justice. Those are the results of an audit which has been published in the UK.

name: Spain in crisis after Catalan vote
voc: [('map out','make a detailed plan'),('goes it alone','does something on its own, without help from others'),('step back from the brink','decide against an action which may have a bad result')]
desc: The Spanish region of Catalonia has voted for independence in an unofficial referendum

name: Greenest summer for UK
voc: [('enjoys','experiences something as an advantage'),('spells trouble','suggests there may be future problems'),('bleed','take a lot of money from')]
desc: Over half of the UK's energy use came from renewable sources, such as wind and solar, this summer.

name: Increase in extremist online content
voc: [('would-be','hoping or trying to be'),('war against','strong and organised effort to control something harmful'),('giants','large, successful, powerful companies')]
desc: The amount of online content created by extremists is growing - and so is the audience for it. A British report says technology companies need to do more to prevent it.

name: Hurricane Irma hits Florida
voc: [('pounds','hits several times with force'),('darkness','sadness; hopelessness'),('in something's wake','after and as a result of an event')]
desc: A devastating hurricane has reached Florida after causing death and destruction across many Caribbean islands.

name: William and Kate expecting third child
voc: [('morning sickness','feeling of wanting to vomit during early pregnancy'),('brand','the way a person or family market themselves'),('in line','likely to receive something')]
desc: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have announced that they are expecting their third child.

name: 450,000 need help in Texan floods
voc: [('death toll','the number of dead people due to an incident'),('obliterate','completely destroy'),('havoc','chaos')]
desc: Tropical storm Harvey has caused massive damage in Texas, where 450,000 people now need help.

name: Online abuse the same as face-to-face
voc: [('trolls','people who intentionally send annoying or insulting online messages'),('corrosive','causing gradual damage to something'),('closes (the) net','restricts the movement or activities of')]
desc: The Director of Public Prosecutions has recommended that the UK treat online hate crime in the same way as face-to-face hate crime.

name: S.Korea urges peaceful end to standoff
voc: [('provocations','actions or speech causing an angry reaction'),('overshadowed','made to seem less important'),('mum','silent')]
desc: The South Korean president has requested that the USA and North Korea peacefully resolve their current argument

name: Anti-diversity Google engineer fired
voc: [('slams','criticises strongly'),('contentious','causing argument or disagreement'),('hits a nerve','upsets someone')]
desc: A Google employee has sent an internal email stating that men and women are biologically different and this affects their choice of jobs. He has been criticised by many and has now lost his job.

name: Apple criticised for stopping VPN apps in China
voc: [('circumvent','avoid a problem or issue'),('capitulation','agreement - often made unwillingly'),('scramble','move quickly to do something')]
desc: Apple will remove all downloadable virtual private network (VPN) apps in its mainland China store to stop the population being able to access websites which the Chinese government have censored.

name: Money can buy happiness
voc: [('chores','boring but necessary tasks'),('underrated','not given the high level of approval it deserves'),('outsourcing','paying someone else to do your tasks for you')]
desc: Money which is used to free up your time makes you happier than money which is spent on material things, such as shoes, Canadian scientists have reported.

name: Sexist advertisements to be banned in the UK
voc: [('watchdog','organisation responsible for making sure people maintain standards and follow the law'),('perpetuate','make something continue'),('unveil','make known for the first time')]
desc: Adverts which show men and women in 'old-fashioned' gender stereotypical roles, for example a woman cleaning a house alone, are to be banned from the UK for maintaining gender inequality.

name: Olympic cities for 2024 and 2028
voc: [('lobbies','tries to persuade people in authority to take a certain action'),('to OK','to agree or give approval for something to happen'),('woo','try to persuade someone to support you by being nice to them')]
desc: Is it going to be Paris or Los Angeles? The International Olympic Committee is expected to accept bids from both cities, but which will get to host the greatest sporting show on earth first?

name: A place for love in Cuba
voc: [('comeback','when something or someone becomes popular again'),('rousing','exciting and inspirational'),('exorbitant','a price which is too high')]
desc: Cuban lovers looking for some privacy can now rent rooms by the hour. So-called 'love motels' are opening again after 20 years.

name: UK National Health Service mail error
voc: [('blunder','a mistake often caused by carelessness'),('mislaid','temporarily lost due to forgetting where it was put'),('backlog','a number of tasks that should have been done by now')]
desc: The UK National Health Service has made a serious mistake with some patient records. Dan and Catherine teach you the language the world's media is using to discuss this story.

name: Day 1 of Britain's EU divorce talks
voc: [('caves in','accepts an unwanted position after being put under pressure'),('lock horns','begin a debate, argument or fight'),('rules out','decides against')]
desc: Britain has to change its plans on day one of Brexit talks. Neil and Catherine teach you the language the world's media is using to discuss this story.

name: Seductive vegetables boost sales
voc: [('indulgent','allowing you to do something when you shouldn't'),('decadent','pleasant but immoral'),('jazzier','brighter, more colourful and more attractive')]
desc: A Stanford psychological study has shown that vegetables labelled in a seductive manner sell better.

name: British Airways' embarrassing mistake
voc: [('human error','a mistake made by a person'),('meltdown','the complete failure of a system'),('fiasco','a complete and embarrassing failure')]
desc: British Airways says that the delays in its service over the weekend were because of a person making a mistake

name: Supercharged antibiotics
voc: [('hail','publicly praise'),('supercharge','make more powerful'),('packs a punch','has great effect or power')]
desc: Scientists from the USA have upgraded an old antibiotic making it 1000 times more powerful!

name: Brazil president welcomes corruption investigation
voc: [('oust ','force someone out of a position of power'),('crumbles','becomes weaker in power or influence'),('glimmer of hope','small sign of something positive to come')]
desc: The Brazilian president has been accused of corruption. However, he is confident that he has done nothing wrong.

name: International cyber-attack
voc: [('surge ','a sudden increase'),('ransomware ','a virus designed to stop a computer working unless money is paid'),('stopped in its tracks','stop moving or doing something suddenly')]
desc: There's been an international cyber-attack which caused chaos across public services and government organisations. Neil and Dan teach you the language the world's media is using to discuss this story.

name: France elects a new president
voc: [('a landslide victory','winning an election by a very large majority'),('an uphill battle','something that's difficult to achieve'),('a breath of fresh air','something or someone new, interesting and exciting')]
desc: France has elected its youngest president ever. 39-year-old Emmanuel Macron beat Marine Le Pen by 66 to 34 percent.

name: Deal struck to end strike
voc: [('averted','stopped something bad from happening'),('tentative','not certain or definite'),('looms','causes worry')]
desc: Hollywood screenwriters have reached a deal to prevent the first strike in 10 years. Neil and Dan teach you how to use the language the world's media is using to discuss this story.

name: Exercise and the brain
voc: [('sharp','mentally quick and intelligent'),('keep (something) at bay','prevent (something) from happening'),('stints','limited periods of time spent doing an activity')]
desc: According to recent research, exercise not only keeps your body healthy, but your brain too. This reduces the risk of memory loss and other conditions of the mind.

name: Express your feelings
voc: [('stiff upper lip','quality of not showing feelings in a difficult situation'),('opens up','starts to talk about feelings'),('went off the rails','started to behave in a way that's not socially acceptable')]
desc: Prince William says not expressing your feelings can lead to mental health problems. His brother, Prince Harry, has said he had counselling after 20 years of "not thinking" about the death of their mother.

name: Measles spreads
voc: [('outbreak','sudden start and spread of a disease'),('sweeping','moving and spreading quickly'),('shun','avoid deliberately')]
desc: The World Health Organisation is warning that diseases like measles could spread because some familes are choosing not to vaccinate their children.

name: A disease from the past
voc: [('comeback','a return of something after a period of time'),('resurgence','the start of something again which used to happen'),('archaic','old; belonging to the past')]
desc: Doctors in Australia are blaming poor modern diets for a rise in the number of people suffering from scurvy. The disease has been diagnosed in seven diabetic patients in Sydney.

name: Who can read your smartphone messages?
voc: [('privacy','right to keep personal information secret'),('encryption','action of putting information into a code to keep it secret'),('backdoor','secret route into a secure system')]
desc: Criminals and terrorists are using private messaging apps to organise their attacks. Now the British government wants access to private smartphone messages.

name: Brexit to begin
voc: [('trigger','make something start'),('kicking off','starting'),('invoking','using a law to achieve something')]
desc: Nine months after British people voted to leave the European Union, the Brexit process is about to begin. Neil and Dan look at the language the world's media is using to discuss this story - and show you how you can use it in your everyday English.

name: Hackers locking people out of their phones
voc: [('rise of','growth of (a significant, powerful phenomenon) '),('held to ransom','made to do something by threats '),('targeting','directing something at someone')]
desc: Cyber criminals are hacking people's smartphones and other digital devices and demanding money from their owners.

name: North Korean murder mystery
voc: [('tit-for-tat','describes actions taken as revenge'),('boils','gets very angry'),('blasts','criticises strongly')]
desc: An argument has developed between Malaysia and North Korea after Kim Jong-un's half-brother was murdered in Kuala Lumpur

name: Space tourists to visit the Moon
voc: [('mission','flight into space'),('venture','new activity that involves risk, often related to business'),('manned','controlled by people')]
desc: It's been 45 years since humans visited the Moon; next year a private company is offering to take space tourists on a trip round Earth's satellite.

name: Thousands of elephants killed in Gabon
voc: [('carnage','the killing of large numbers of people or animals'),('poachers','people who catch and  kill animals illegally to eat or sell'),('decimate','destroy or kill a large number')]
desc: 25,000 elephants have been killed by illegal hunters in Gabon in the last ten years. That's 80% of the elephant population in the country.

name: Dam at risk of bursting
voc: [('evacuate','leave a place because of danger'),('overflow','spill liquid because there's too much'),('race against the clock','try to complete something urgent in a short space of time')]
desc: The tallest dam in the United States is damaged and may collapse. Thousands of people have been told to leave their homes while urgent repairs are carried out.

name: Beckham's email hacked
voc: [('leak','the act of making private information known to the public'),('blackmail','get money from someone by threatening to reveal their secrets '),('fury','extreme anger')]
desc: David Beckham's emails have been hacked - and they appear to show that the former footballer was very angry about not being given the title 'Sir'. The hackers demanded money to keep the emails secret.

name: Trump dismisses US attorney general over immigration ban
voc: [('sack / fire','remove from a job'),('defying','refusing to obey'),('betrayal','act of not being loyal')]
desc: US President Donald Trump has removed Sally Yates because she told lawyers not to enforce his immigration ban on people from seven Muslim-majority countries.

name: Can toast cause cancer?
voc: [('over______','Used as a prefix to mean 'too much' '),('potential','describes something possible in the right circumstances '),('browned off','annoyed')]
desc: Toast and roast potatoes should be golden rather than brown. That's according to a UK government agency who has warned that certain burnt foods could cause cancer.

name: Democrats to skip Trump inauguration
voc: [('boycott','refuse to take part in something as a protest'),('legitimate','allowed by the law'),('swell','get bigger')]
desc: Donald Trump will become the 45th president of the United States on Friday 20th January. But many members of Congress from the opposition party, the Democrats, are refusing to attend.

name: The World Cup expands
voc: [('the bulk of','most of; the majority of'),('facelift','a change that improves something'),('set to','organised so that something happens in the future')]
desc: Football is the world's most popular sport - and its biggest competiton is going to get even bigger. The World Cup will have 48 teams playing in the finals from 2026.

name: Vinyl records make a comeback
voc: [('tangible','something real, that you can touch'),('embraced','welcomed with enthusiasm'),('record high','highest amount reached'),('turning the tables','changing from the weaker position to the stronger')]
desc: It's a format many thought would die, but vinyl records sold more copies in 2016 than in the last 25 years. What's the appeal of these black, plastic disks?
